author: yogo
title: 21st century Agri supply chain
description: Agricultural supply chains are broken resulting in poverty for smallholder farmers and environmental degradation.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is quite ambitious and if successful will have a large impact both in Ghana but the broader African economy. However, it is unclear how it aligns with the success metrics and objectives of this particular challenge. The proposal is largely focused on the development of a new supply chain, as opposed to what the challenge requests which is the development of foundational registry solutions. As such, if there was a link made around the way this solution could interact with existing government bodies or whether it plans to entirely replace the need for government interaction was made unclear. 

In order to turn this from a good to an excellent proposal, I suggest narrowing the scope to truly address the key problem statement at hand. For example, narrowing down on one of the key activities such as 'gathering farmer information' and putting this on-chain would be a sufficient proposal. This could then capture information on the farmer, farm details, crop information, etc… In the process of providing a lot of information for the proposal, the key takeaway and objective is left lost for the reader and voter. 

A key strength in the proposal from an impact perspective is the collaboration with the stakeholders (farmers). However, this again falls short in describing how it aims to build a strategy to engage governments, other partners and organisation's.
f6_assessments.q1:
One of the strengths of this proposal is the demonstration of the depth of skills and experience in the execution team. Roles ranging from project , product and business model leads. However, there appears to be a gap for someone that strongly understands the application of blockchain technology.  

The budget of $22.5k USD makes up a smaller proportion of the total $800k allocation for the challenge.  The budget is high-level and is not clearly broken down at a detailed level. For example, if you are requesting $2000 USD for the business proposal, how many days are allocating to this activity? How many people are allocated towards building this out? These same questions can be applied to every other budgeted item. 

Finally, the proposal does not  clearly address the key challenges to deliver the project successfully.  It mentions that it has already addressed the potential challenge of building trust. However, from past experience running projects both technical and strategy, it is vital to have a log of risks to watch out for, whether that is related to delivering the project on time, communication challenges, iterations requirements as product strategy evolves, etc… Highlighting what these biggest challenges that they could face would provide a realistic colour to what lies ahead and what actions are required to overcome them.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal can benefit from going into more detail when addressing the ability to audit the progress. For example, whilst there are high-level comments on how to track the progress such as having 'monthly-status documents', having a detailed roadmap that clearly links to the key value drops and how long it will take would give the community an added layer of comfort that the project will be properly managed and delivered. Further, there is a lack of specificity in the metrics used to track progress. For example 'increased income by > X%' is not a metric. What is the percentage value increase you are truly after? Can you select more direct metrics for value-add such as 'signing up 1500 farmers on to the platform' or 'signing up 10 different produce types.'

f6_assessments.q0:
The Nation Building Dapps challenge mentions two broad directions proposals can take: First; assist with basic government services where these are insufficient, such as governance, welfare, education, utilities and so on that can be bootstrapped from inadequate to world-class web3, and Second; increase the number of Dapp users in developing countries in general, and increase human development outside government services can also be seen as a decentralized layer of Nation Building. This proposal has potential in both, but it more relevant in the second. It explicitly mentions the potential for Dapp usage after the proposed research and the arguments presented are highly credible. Essentially, small-holder farming and agricultural supply chains in Africa (Ghana initially) operate very inefficiently and unfairly for the farmers, and can bring a lot of people to use Dapps and improve their livelihoods with decentralized web3 building blocks.
The proposal is the starting point for a much larger project envisioned. It will not have any Dapp launch or improvements "on the ground" as the desired result, but wants to accurately measure the status quo and potential. This will be done collaboratively with involvement of WADA, the Pond Foundation, Earthworm, AIM and C4C and the findings will be made available to the public / Townhall.
The proposal ticks all the boxes, but will "only" result in another proposal if successful. While this boosts feasibility and auditability, it comes at the cost of impact. I still assess this as a good fit and effectively addressing the challenge in terms of overall impact.
f6_assessments.q1: The large and highly experienced team of proposers showcases Catalyst collaboration at its best, bringing together leaders and pioneers in impact investment, NGOs, Africa-specific knowledge and web3 solutions. The proposal is highly realistic, limiting its scope to research and creating a much more ambitious roadmap for the actual web3 integration as a long term goal. It is well structured, backed up by references and milestones, and shares insight in project management tools and metrics. Given all the information presented, I consider it highly likely that the vision for success described can be achieved.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal has over a dozen KPIs. It is highly detailed about how progress will be communicated back to the community and stakeholders. It is also good that immediate success of the presented proposal is compared to and treated separately from the longer term project.
The product metrics presented demonstrate how much thought has gone into the proposal and all of them seem highly relevant to improving agricultural supply chains and the livelihoods of farmers.
I would have liked to see a separation of phases 1 and 2 under auditability and a discussion of the timeline with regard to auditability. Overall, I am highly confident that the progress towards success will be communicated clearly.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal involves the ‘research and solution concept testing’ for the subsequent development of various DApps for the Agricultural products supply chain. This proposal falls under the Challenge because the Agri-products Supply chain problems are the national problems being faced by many African countries. 
 The solution being developed will have a big impact on the lives of many people and on the ecology as well.
The solutions proposed under this proposal will have the ability to scale as it is being prepared on the ground-up approach. The proposer will be considering all the probable issues faced by the people and the whole supply chain and provide suitable solutions for them. Hence once completed the proposed DApps and the platform can be scaled to include larger geography.
This proposal will likely be bringing many users to the Cardano ecosystem in the guise of various parties involved in the Agriculture production and its supply chain at least in the farming of “Bambara Groundnut” in Ghana and hopefully, this project progress to include other Agricultural products and a lot of farmlands across Africa in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team is qualified to carry out the proposal as it is the team of well-known organizations i.e., ‘Pond foundation’ and ‘whatif-foods’ company. The execution team will also include some Cardano community members from WADA. The pond foundation founder and this proposal lead Mr. Scott Ponynton is a well-experienced individual whose works range from no-deforestation, forest protection, regenerative supply chains, and various collaborations and efforts to fight climate change. ‘Whatif-foods’ is one of the world-leading providers of sustainable agricultural products.
The roadmap for this research phase has been divided and described into identifiable tasks. The budget also seems to be reasonable. It is distributed into the different tasks to complete Phase 1. 
 I think that the tasks to be completed can be further elaborated and the given timeframe of 3 months for phase 1 should be divided on weekly basis.
The proposer did not describe how they will arrange the funding for Phase 2 and Phase 3. It will be better if that also can be stated.
The proposal is likely to be completed in view of the above positive contributors.
f6_assessments.q2:
As stated by the proposer the proposal can be audited by examining the study reports and attending various Catalyst and other meetings regarding the status of the proposal.
In my opinion, if the tasks to be completed can be split up into weekly tasks that will help for easy follow-up and auditing.
Key metrics and milestones are defined clearly by the proposer but being the research phase this proposal’s metrics are limited. We have to wait for the subsequent phases to get completed to witness the true impact and other sustainable goals of this project.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is very well structured and fitting for this challenge. Focussing on the "Research and solution concept testing" phase is indeed a wise way to build up momentum, deliver quantifiable results that the community can review and potentially contribute to. Even if the team is already well experienced and connected, it would be interesting to see how community members can contribute to this initiative as at the end of the day, the concept if that of a "supply chain", where different groups can potentially provide services like ecommerce, marketing, data and analytics etc...

Ultimately, the proposal can lead to design patterns for such sustainable supply chains that could be composable from a set of decentralized microservices.
f6_assessments.q1:

It would be useful however to understand who is working on what, at what capacity for efficiency. Potentially investing in a  collaboration platform from day 1,  can also help organize resources / deliverables to ensure that a geographically distributed team can work efficiently.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal team is working on a project that addresses the problem of restoring and developing the agricultural supply chain and has the common goal of reducing poverty for smallholder farmers as well as reducing environmental degradation. I think this project has great significance for the development of the community and the potential of the project is also great.
The proposal explains the concept of the project very well with illustrations. How the project works is also described in great detail and presented in a way that is easy to grasp. In addition, the impact of the project on potential audiences is also mentioned very specifically in the proposal. The solution section is extremely detailed and explains the technical aspects in depth. Overall, the proposal met the requirements of the challenge in terms of impact on the Cardano community.
The results brought by the project are aimed at improving the agricultural situation and are presented in great detail. These results show the synchronization with the Key metrics that the challenge has set. The results also show the economic and financial development potential of the project when completed. From there, you can also see the impact on the Cardano ecosystem.
The proposers assumed that the project would not present significant challenges. Due to a very clear grasp of the situation, the proposal proposes small challenges that are likely to form during project implementation and also offers appropriate solutions and workarounds to minimize risks when implementing the project.
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap is divided into 3 phases by the team. Each stage is accompanied by specific timelines for completing the set work items. The work plan is specific and reasonable, stating the requirements for the work items. The presentation is also very clear for viewers to easily follow. But the proposal still does not mention the positions and the number of people needed to participate in the project. If possible, think about this and add that information to the proposal.
Phase 1 with a total budget of 22,500 USD is divided into investment items. The budget plan is presented very clearly and it is easy to track the spending of the project. However, as mentioned before, I think there should be a part of the budget for staff salaries and it should be listed in this budget plan.
The project management and implementation team consist of people with high professional knowledge and extensive experience. With their background knowledge and experience as well as skills, the team promises to execute the project according to the given plan.
f6_assessments.q2:
It will be easier for the community to track and evaluate project progress if the proposal provides specific metrics and clear quantitative indicators. Based on these indicators, the community can assess the success of the project.
The success of Phase 1 of the project is clearly visualized through the criteria to evaluate the success of the project. The information that the proposal provides is very complete. The results are generally in line with the blueprint. This shows the seriousness of the group's implementation of the set goals.
